Translation of 楚竹書・陳公治兵(en) into English.

p.seg: The king went to Gu;
as there was at the moment peace in the state of Chu.
The king then first settled on top of X (an observation point?),
to inspect the army.
Then he ordered the army
to go to kill and fetch wild animals (?) pheasants and rabbits (?),
and when the army then dispersed (?), he did not [...]
[...] move them at the back,
to meet with the king's soldiers,
they then marched after the three drums,
getting deeply into the king's soldiers' (ranks),
they didn't stop,
and then the drum beat (again?),
and then they marched on.
The king enjoyed this,
and then (finally) ordered Duke Kuang of Cheng to stop it.
Duke Kuang of Cheng obeyed,
then went to put the army in order.
Duke Cheng then had the army's superintendant come,
lord Lu [...]
[...] He also returned to the king to make the army march fast,
the soldiers were all startled,
then they all got into their ranks.
Duke Cheng returned to listen to the orders of the king:
"You, my king, have ignored my unworthiness,
and ordered me to help the attendants
to put the army in order.
Don't I know that if one leads the army to come to the king's seat
then one prevents the army from marching?
Don't I know that if the vanguard breaks into the (army's) lines
and enters into the royal army's (ranks, disrupting them),
one should (still) not stop the army from marching?
The king told Duke Cheng:
"If when they enter my ranks
you could still manage not to stop the army from marching,
wouldn't this be really perfect?"
Duke Cheng [...]
[...] this,
the lord did not recognize my (Kuang's) lack of talent,
and ordered me (Kuang) to help the superintendants
to put the army in order,
so that they would necessarily carry out well the orders (?),
ordering their assistants (?) to line up (the army) at the two sides of the chariot (?),
putting groups of five people into squads of five (?),
groups of ten into lines (?).
If the lines are not properly ordered,
and platoons(?) do not lead platoons,
the following of orders (?) is discarded.
The petty man [here =I?] considers important the chariot [=the rule is to consider the chariot important in the open field]
He also keeps the eight drums and the five tunes,
bells and cymbals on the left,
drums on the right,
with metal bells to make them sit,
wooden bells to make them stand,
drums to make them advance
and horseback drums to make them stop,
the "X heroic" tune to make them brave (?),
the "lofty mountain" tune to make them retreat.
there is what is referred to as majesty,
there is what is referred to as respect,
there is what is referred to as moderation,
there is what is referred to as unity,
there is what is referred to as concentration.
Duke Kuang of Cheng then sat down:
As for the old events of the state of Chu
(we) fought in Cai and Qiu,
the fight went on (?).
Xiong Xue (?) and Zi Pi fought in Luo Zhou (?) with the Ba people,
the fight went on (?),
until we captured their insignia (?).
Qu Ping and Ba ordered Yi to fight in Xi (?),
we fought and brought him under control (?).
The former king Wu fought with the Yuan (?) people in Pu Mo,
the fight went on (?).
The former king Wen [...] fought on the banks of the Xu Zhang,
the fight went on (?).
Also, we fought with the people of Jin in Liang Tang,
the fight went on (?).
If we go among the people of Jiu,
and send our army there,
if we move the army,
and the commanders of the left and of the right offer advice to the general,
asking him to send the soldiers out,
and the general agrees with the commanders of the left and of the right [...]
then the army sets out,
and is deployed with its back to the camp,
and the general sets out (?).
one then calls it "covered march",
like when they close their ranks in defence (?),
like when they charge against (the enemies') closed ranks,
like when they close up the (communication) roads (of the enemy) (?),
like when they assault (the enemies) on their (communication) roads (?),
like when they pursue (the enemies),
one must be careful ...(???)
[...] the soldiers carrying firewood (?),
encircling their guards (?)
like when they reinforce the city walls (?),
or when they are deployed on both sides of the encampment and keep connections among them (the two sides) (?),
one must be careful.
if they are deployed in hilly terrain (?),
then they should adopt the formation of the flying wild geese [with a few people at the front and most at the back?].
If they are deployed in the open fields,
if they meet high grass or frost,
the chariots should then ...
The soldiers on foot and the armored soldiers stay at the back,
when (the army) is deployed on the bulwarks
then the soldiers on foot and the armored soldiers (can) advance and retreat
